question: Bandits at 2 o'clock.
answer: Power dive!

question: It's Germans!
answer: Kill the bastards!

question: Good shooting, Danny!
answer: Good shooting, Rafe!

question: Land of the free...
answer: Home of the brave!

question: There's another one!
answer: Daddy, I told you I was comin' here. Da!... Dad...

question: Let him alone!
answer: Rafe... Daddy... No!

question: I'll bust you open, you...German!
answer: Daddy! Daddy! Wait.

question: Aw, shit...
answer: Yee-hawww!!! Where's Rafe?

question: You're down, Walker! That's an order!
answer: What about him?

question: He's not taking my orders anymore.
answer: He's gonna do it.

question: He's gonna do it.
answer: Do what?

question: It. Aw, shit. Aw shit shit shit... I shouldn't'a done an inside loop. I shouldn't'a done an inside loop.
answer: Why?

question: There are some people who think the outside loop is reckless and irresponsible.
answer: How could it be irresponsible, Sir, if you were the first man in the world to do it?

question: Don't get smart with me, son.
answer: Never, Sir. I just meant it's dangerous only for the kind of pilot who wants to show off, rather than inspire the other pilots in his unit. And all you've done for me, Sir, working out the transfer, I did it to say thanks. To honor you, Sir. What the French call a "homage."

question: That's bullshit, son. But it's really good bullshit.
answer: Thank you, Sir.

question: Good luck over there McCawley. I admire your decision.
answer: Thank you, Sir.

question: Doolittle didn't kill you? Attaboy!
answer: Danny, there's something I gotta tell you...

question: How could you do this?
answer: The Colonel helped me work it out.

question: I don't mean how'd you do the paperwork, I mean how the hell did you do it without letting me in on it?
answer: I'm sorry, Danny, but they're only accepting the best pilots.

question: Don't make this a joke, Rafe. You're talking about war, and I know what war does to people.
answer: Danny, you know how many times I saw you come to school with a black eye or a busted nose, and couldn't do a thing about it -- for you, or for your mother... or your father, with his lungs scorched out with mustard gas, and more left of his lungs than there was of his spirit? You've made your sacrifice, Danny. It's time I made mine.

question: He's taken. But come on, I'll introduce you.
answer: Hello, Lieutenant. Good to see you.

question: You too, Lieutenant. Oh, this is Betty.
answer: Nice to meet you, Betty. Danny would'a brought this.

question: Danny's not coming?
answer: No, he...got some news today. He'll be okay, he just didn't feel like coming tonight.

question: He, I'm R-Red. Red S-Strange.
answer: Red...Strange?

question: You know the football player, Red G- Grange? Well the guys called me R-Red, cause you know, I'm red...and they thought I was strange, so, you know, Red G-Grange, Red Str-Strange.
answer: But...they called you Strange? Because of Red Grange? I don't get it. Was Red Grange strange?

question: How would I know.
answer: Do you always stutter?

question: Only when I'm n-n-n-
answer: Nervous?

question: Yeah. But if I have to get something out, I c-can always s-s-s- SIIING!
answer: Don't be nervous.

question: Whatever you're trying to tell me isn't good, is it. Or it wouldn't be so hard to say.
answer: The only reason it's hard to say is that I keep thinking I don't have the right to say it. But I've got to because it's true. I love you. That must surprise you.

question: It surprises me that I'm not the only one on this balcony who feels that way.
answer: There's one thing I have to say. I'm going away.

question: We're all going away.
answer: I'm going to the war. The real war. Hitler's taken Europe. The Brits are hanging on by their fingernails, and If they lose, there'll be more people killed than anybody can imagine. And not just there, but here.

question: But you're in the U.S. Army, how could you --
answer: Colonel Doolittle pulled the strings, and put me on loan to the R.A.F. They need pilots, and we need experience. I leave tomorrow.

question: You waited til tonight to tell me?
answer: I had to tell you in person. Because there's something else I need to say. Evelyn...you know the line -- let's make tonight memorable. What I feel about you makes it impossible for me to say something like that. If I don't come back, I don't want to saddle you with regret and sadness you'll carry the rest of your life.

question: I don't know if you can choose that, Rafe.
answer: Maybe not. But I need you to know. I love you. And I will come back. I'll find a way. And then we'll get a chance to know if what I felt the first moment I saw you, and every minute since then, is real.

question: Didn't you say you told her not to come?
answer: Yeah.

question: Then why are you looking for her?
answer: It's a test. If I asked her to come and she came, it wouldn't tell me anything. If I tell her not to come, and she comes...then I know she loves me.

question: You're still a kid, ya know that? Take care of yourself.
answer: You too.

question: Give 'em hell, Rafe.
answer: Rafe McCawley, Sir.

question: Rafe McCawley, Sir.
answer: On loan from Colonel Doolittle, is it?

question: That's me, Sir.
answer: Good on you, then, Rafe McCawley. We'll get you situated in some quarters, and then introduce you to the equipment you'll be flying.

question: If you're patching up bullet holes right here on the runway, maybe we should skip the housekeeping and get right to the planes.
answer: Are all the Yanks as anxious as you are to get yourself killed, Lieutenant?

question: Not anxious to die, Sir, anxious to matter.
answer: Good lad. Didn't die till he'd landed and shut down his engine. Welcome to the war.

question: Hey. You. Mr. Coma.
answer: Where's that lizard?

question: What lizard?
answer: The one that slept in my mouth last night.

question: What the hell happened to you guys?
answer: Ever hear of mai-tai's? Comes in a big...pot. Like...like...

question: Look at the ships -- all grouped. Perfect targets!
answer: Sitting ducks. They think no one would be stupid enough to attack them at Pearl Harbor.

question: Or perhaps they think no one is capable. Look at this... Pearl Harbor's depth of only forty feet makes them feel safe. A torpedo dropped from an airplane plunges to one hundred feet before it can level off. That is a conventional torpedo. But we have been experimenting. Wooden fins. We are testing them tomorrow. We have chosen this place because its depth is exactly the same as Pearl Harbor's.
answer: Uncharged torpedoes have different balance.

question: Leapin' Jesus!
answer: The struts are loose, the hydraulics are leaking, and the electrical system's shorting out in the cockpit.

question: Well which of those three ya want fixed?
answer: All of 'em.

question: If ye'd wanted a bloody Cadillac ya should'a stayed in the bloody States!
answer: And if you don't give me a plane that can handle combat, you better start learning to speak German.

question: Fook ya!
answer: Learn English, then!

question: Fook ya dooble! I have'na been able ta --
answer: Crank her!

question: God speed ya, laddie.
answer: Here they come. We've got him hurt, stay on him! We've got him going! I can't see the clouds!

question: Can I help you, sailor?
answer: 'Scuse me, 'Mam. All the ship's doctors is golfing, and I couldn't find nobody to look at this.

question: Our doctor's gone too.
answer: Sorry to trouble you.

question: Wait, let me look at that... You better come in here. How'd you get this?
answer: Boxin'.

question: Win?
answer: Yes'm.

question: What's your name?
answer: Dorie Miller, 'Mam.

question: I'm Evelyn. And I'm just a nurse. But I'm not playing golf, and that cut needs sewing, or else it's gonna make a big lumpy scar. Whatta ya say? How often you fight like this?
answer: Every other Sunday. I'm heavyweight champion of the West Virginia.

question: What do you get for winning?
answer: Respect. No doctor would'a give me that good. Thank you, 'Mam.

question: Tell me something, Dorie. A man as big as you -- and smart too, you knew where to come when your ship couldn't help -- do you still have to fight with your fists to get respect?
answer: I left my Mama and joined the Navy to be a man. They made me a cook -- and not even that, really -- I clean up after the other sailors eat. I shine the officer's shoes. In two years, they've never even let me fire a gun.

question: You take care, Dorie.
answer: You too, 'Mam.

question: ...Rafe...
answer: Lieutenant... I'm Danny Walker. I'm Rafe McCawley's best friend.

question: Were. Isn't that what you mean? Were. Because he's dead, isn't he? And that's why you've come.
answer: Before Rafe left, he asked me to be the one to tell you, if it happened.

question: He told me about you. That he had no other friend like you.
answer: Rafe's folks had a crop dusting business, owned their own planes. Real straight, frugal. My father was the town drunk. Went to sleep one night on the railroad tracks and was still there when the Dawn Express came along. Rafe and I were the only ones at the funeral. He took me back to his house, and I never left.

question: You were more like brothers.
answer: I taught him to drink beer. He taught me how to fly.

question: He said you're the only one he ever saw who was better in the air than him.
answer: ...He said that? Look, uh...Rafe's dad...he wrote me with the news, and it took me a couple of days to work up the guts to come here and tell you. I'm not as brave as Rafe, or as noble. But if there's anything I can ever do to help -- you let me know, okay? I understand why Rafe loved you. You're as strong as he was.

question: Everything real except the fact that no one is shooting back at us.
answer: If we achieve surprise, they will offer little resistance.

question: Set up teams of radio operators to send out messages the Americans will intercept, concerning every potential American target in the Pacific. Include Hawaii -- the clutter will be more confusing that way.
answer: Brilliant, Admiral.

question: You're Walker, right?
answer: Yes Sir.

question: That was a nice little stunt you pulled, buzzing the base.
answer: You liked that?

question: Oh yeah. I liked it so much I'm cutting you out of the squadron.
answer: Sir?

question: I don't buy that hot dog shit. So you and your buddies are gonna transfer your planes up to Haleiwa.
answer: Hale-what?

question: You'll love it. No base, no bars, just lots of sun and aircraft maintenance.
answer: Sir, I --

question: Too late for apologies, Walker.
answer: I wasn't gonna apologize, Sir. I was just gonna say it was worth it to feel like a real pilot again, even if it was only for five seconds. How's everything?

question: I wasn't gonna apologize, Sir. I was just gonna say it was worth it to feel like a real pilot again, even if it was only for five seconds. How's everything?
answer: We got some soldiers in traction from a jeep accident, but it's quiet. Except for the occasional fighter plane buzzing us.

question: That might not have been such a good idea. They're making us fly out of a half-paved airfield. The real punishment is that I won't be back to the barracks till it's too late for dinner or coffee. So I guess it's goodbye for awhile.
answer: I was just thinking that war is a series of goodbyes. Do you think that's why we're meeting. To help us say goodbye to Rafe?

question: I swore not to talk about him tonight, but there's all this stuff I think I ought to tell you, that he didn't get a chance to. Rafe was...he was lonely. He had such high expectations of himself that he always felt empty. The week he met you he told me he felt his heart had always lived in winter, and for the first time in his life he has seen the spring. Sorry.
answer: He told me he didn't want to leave me with regret. Now that's all I have.

question: Hey, have you seen Pearl Harbor at night?
answer: Well...sure.

question: From the air?
answer: So beautiful!

question: Hang on.
answer: I didn't realize until tonight that I've stopped wanting to live.

question: Evelyn. I sent telegrams, I guess the military traffic held them up.
answer: Why were you sitting here, instead of...

question: I saw you, I couldn't go in, I...just stood there wondering if you knew. You looked...sad, and I had to sit down a minute.
answer: How did you?...

question: ...Survive? I jumped in a patch of fog, and nobody could see me. I hit the water hard. And it was so...cold. I don't know how long I was in the water. A Norwegian freighter picked me up. They were headed to Spain. They docked in La Rota, right beside a German ship, and told me to stay hidden below. I was afraid they'd turn me in, so I stole some clothes, jumped ship, and found a church, where the priest contacted the resistance, and got me on a freighter to New York. I called my folks, then Colonel Doolittle. The Colonel sent a man to pick me up. They wanted to debrief me. I told the Colonel I needed to see somebody first, and he had a supply flight heading out in an hour. I've done a lot of talking. You haven't said anything.
answer: I'm just...so amazed, so glad to know that you're okay. You are okay, aren't you?

question: Nothing that won't heal. I guess.
answer: It's been...so different, being so sure you were dead.

question: I'm so sorry for what you must've gone through, but I'm back. Maybe I've assumed too much. Has something changed? I'm afraid to ask what. And I'm afraid not to. Have you fallen in love? It's all right. Danny always said I see things with my emotions instead of my eyes.
answer: It's not your fault, Rafe. The letter I wrote you, they --

question: Don't worry about that. Guys away from home, lonely, good-hearted women try to cheer them up.
answer: It's not that I didn't mean everything I wrote. It's just that -- I thought you were dead. And now --

question: They'll go under you because their planes are faster, then they run so you can't catch 'em. But then they'll come around and take you from behind -- like some Americans will. Sorry.
answer: Why be sorry? That's what you feel, it's better to come out with it.

question: I didn't mean it.
answer: Sure you did. So come on. Say what you think.

question: Waitress! Four beers!
answer: You don't wanna put beer over mai-tai.

question: If you can't keep up, don't drink yours. We gotta face some facts here.
answer: What facts are those?

question: I understand how it could happen. I know why any guy would love her. And I can't blame you that it happened. You thought I was dead, she was grieving, you were trying to help her.
answer: I was grieving too.

question: Yeah, right. Anyway, you didn't know.
answer: So what are you saying?

question: I'm saying now you do know. So it's time for you to fuck off.
answer: You left her. How's that for a fact?

question: How's this for a fact? I loved her first.
answer: You know, you're a lousy drinker. Drinking's supposed to make men feel bigger. It only makes you stupid. And weak.

question: How's this?
answer: You want it, you got it.

question: How come you're not pukin'?
answer: I guess I'm used to it. I've felt like throwing up every minute since you got back. Don't blame her, Rafe. It's not like you're thinking.

question: Fuck you.
answer: She loves you. I know that. And part of what she loves in me is how much of you she sees in me. We were both torn up. I started dropping by to see her, because we understood what each other felt. We'd have coffee and try not to talk about you, but we always would. She said I was so much like you. I said, No, I'm not. I'm like I am because of you, but I'm not you, not as good as you. Everybody else saw me as a loser with a big chip on his shoulder. But you saw the better part of me, the part of me that could be like you, and changed me. You made me who I am.

question: Come with us!
answer: Where are we going?

question: Auxiliary field at Haleiwa, ten miles north of here.
answer: What's there?

question: Six P-40's.
answer: Sum-bitch!

question: They ready, Earl?
answer: They'll all fly, but -- oh, shit...

question: Cover!
answer: You absolute mother-fuckin' son of a bitch! You shot one of my planes!

question: You hear my okay?
answer: Yeah. So you can call me if you need help.

question: I got a half a tank. You?
answer: Little less.

question: They're in strafing formation, we'll blow right through their line. Land of the free.
answer: Home of the brave.

question: Rafe --
answer: I need to tell you something. I didn't know what it was to lose somebody, to see death and find how much it scares you. That you haven't lived and loved enough. I didn't understand. Forgive me.

question: Rafe... No. You forgive me.
answer: Of course I forgive you. I know what you feel for Danny is real. And your choice is your choice.

question: That's what I have to tell you, Rafe. It wasn't a choice. It --
answer: Yes, Major.

question: You mean the hula shirts you were flying in?... Or the six planes you shot down? You're both being awarded the Silver Star, and promoted to captain.
answer: Is that the good new, Sir, or --

question: You're just about the only pilots in the Army with actual combat experience, so you're volunteering for a mission I've been ordered to put together. Do you know what top secret is?
answer: Well sure, Colonel --

question: I want to introduce a couple of people. Doc White is a flight surgeon; he has volunteered for gunnery training so that he can go on the mission, because we can't spare the weight of an extra man.
answer: A long range bomber mission.

question: ...And Ross Greening, who will oversee your equipment. Any questions?
answer: Who'll be the first one in, Colonel? I'd like to volunt --

question: Fun today. Like old times.
answer: Danny, what the hell are you trying to do out there?

question: What do you mean? I'm just doing what we've always done.
answer: No. You're trying to beat me.

question: We've always tried to beat each other.
answer: Bullshit. We've played with each other, pushed each other. This is different. Like you want to prove that you're better than me. Who's that for -- Evelyn?

question: Maybe just trying to measure up.
answer: What's between you and her is between you and her. But here's what's between you and me. Everybody has a hero, Danny. And you're mine. When we were growing up, I had everything. You had nothing. You climbed out of a hole I couldn't even see the bottom of. I think maybe when I went off to England, I was trying to measure up to you. Measuring up's over. Let's just look out for each other. Okay?

question: I'm gonna turn in. I hate being on the water. I think this is the last sleep I'll get for awhile. McCawley. What?...
answer: They were bringing back a ship full of wounded and needed extra nurses along. I wrote Colonel Doolittle, and told him I needed to see you before you go.

question: It must of been a convincing letter.
answer: It was. I couldn't have you go away, wherever it is...to war...without knowing something. You think I made a choice, of Danny over you. I didn't. I didn't have a choice. I'm pregnant.

question: Does Danny know?
answer: I wasn't sure, until the day you turned up alive. I never had a chance to tell him. Now I can't have him thinking about this when he needs to be thinking about his mission, and how to come back from it. I want you thinking about that too. Just come back. Rafe, I see it in your face. You're thinking you don't have anything to live for. Don't you dare think that way. I'll never write a letter, or look at a sunset, without thinking of you. I'll love you my whole life. And I want you to live.

question: No. Any other questions?
answer: C-Colonel, we been p-practicing takeoff's, but I ain't sure we can land on these carriers d-decks.

question: We won't have the fuel to get back to the carriers; they'll turn and run back to Hawaii the minute we're airborne.
answer: Then wh-where do we land?

question: I have a phrase I want you all to memorize
answer: A-a-asshole!... Maybe it's l-longer going this way.

question: Since we'll be on our own once we're in the air, I thought I had a good idea letting each crew select it's own target. Now we have fifteen requests for the Emperor's Palace...and one for Tokyo baseball stadium.
answer: I d-don't think Japs ought'a be allowed to p-play baseball.

question: I'd like to bomb their Emperor too. But I think that'd just piss 'em off. The idea here, Gentlemen, is not revenge. We're here to prove to them that they're neither invincible nor superior. So let's try this again. Military targets only.
answer: Colonel, to f-fight you need strategy. To have strategy, ya gotta practice. And to practice it, ya gotta play --

question: No baseball diamonds, Red.
answer: Y-Yes Sir.

question: We have bombed Tokyo, Mr. President. Radio Tokyo interrupted it's own broadcast to make the announcement.
answer: Have the planes made it to China?

question: There've been some complications, Sir. The Chinese didn't receive our request for homing beacons until is was too late to get them set. And the planes had to take off so early they may lack fuel to make the mainland anyway.
answer: So those brave men are flying blind and running out of fuel.

question: The Chinese are sending out search parties to try to find the crews before the Jap patrols do, if any of the planes make it.
answer: God help them.
